data.title: Clicking on a text input places cursor one character off
data.body:
Godot 3.0 master

When I click text input fields, the cursor is placed one character off on the left.

Example: on this screenshot, I clicked at the yellow arrow, but the cursor was placed before.
A similar situation in the script editor doesn't reproduces (not as much).
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/30835701-d5e4298c-a259-11e7-97c9-72d649758c2e.png)

Here is how the "hitbox" feels to place the cursor in between letters:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/30835797-6ffef4ac-a25a-11e7-8d2d-d77902808800.png)
And how it should feel:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/30835801-78618eca-a25a-11e7-9a76-c7499f5c829b.png)

~~Edit: tbh I'm not sure if noting this as bug is worth it, I opened it after a bit of confusion naming a script... maybe it's just me?~~
Yup, brainfart

data.title: Impossible to set a custom editor font when it is outside of the project
data.body:
Godot 3.0 master

I successfully set a custom text editor dynamic font by simply creating one in a project, then assigning it in the editor settings, showing a full path.

Then I opened a new project, and suddenly Godot was unable to load the font. The script editor went empty, showing only small "spaces", and this error:

```
ERROR: FileAccessWindows::_get_modified_time: Method/Function Failed, returning: 0
   At: drivers\windows\file_access_windows.cpp:248
ERROR: DynamicFontAtSize::_load: Condition ' !f ' is true. returned: ERR_CANT_OPEN
   At: scene\resources\dynamic_font.cpp:137
```

I dragged the font resource in my new project, and it worked again.

I expected the font to work from anywhere, since the path to this resource is global.

data.title: MeshInstance.set_mesh(MeshInstance) doesn't fail
data.body:
Godot 2.1.3, Godot 3.0 master
Windows 10 64 bits

After 30 minutes of headbanging, I found the following code runs without producing any error:

```gdscript
var mi = MeshInstance.new()
mi.set_mesh(mi)
```

It should throw a type error.

data.title: Touch event not being registered on Wacom Cintiq
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot v3.0 alpha custom build, Windows 10 PC + Wacom Cintiq tablet

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Godot doesn't recognize touch events when using Wacom Cintiq, meaning it prints out that the input event is left mouse button or mouse motion.  What makes it weirder is that godot also doesn't fire any event when I press the finger on the screen, I actually have to move it, only then the console prints that the left mouse button was pressed and motion event happened.

So the issue is that the touch event doesn't get recognized as touch event, instead it gets recognized as a left mouse button event, and also "pressed" and "released" states get printed out both only after finger was released from the screen, instead of printing "pressed" when finger was pressed and "released" when finger was released off the screen.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Just to clarify it:
1)I press on the screen -nothing happens
2a)I release the finger off the screen - console prints that the left mouse button was pressed and released
2b)I drag the finger - console prints that the left mouse button was pressed and mouse motion happened

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Unwanted transparency in Tilemap
data.body:
**Windows. Godot version 2.1.4**


**Issue description:**
Unwanted transparency


**Steps to reproduce:**
Accidentally imported tiles with around 95% alpha value from Inkscape. Noticed slight transparency immediately in the tilemap, observed that I could faintly see the furthest background objects though the tiles.

I fixed the transparency issue and re-imported all the tiles. Still didn't fix anything in Godot, even though the transparency was gone in the actual tile assets. Made sure Opacity and Self Opacity of tilemap were set to 1. Tried nuking the tilemap and starting from scratch, duplicating the node, nothing worked. Tried using completely new tileset.res- this did work. However, any new tilesets built from the old tiles, even though they were fixed, did not work.

Finally, just for kicks, I tried setting the Opacity and Self-Opacity to 1.1, which reverted back to 1.0 correctly in the editor, and rebuilt my game. It worked, and the transparency is no longer there.

So the issue appears to be the tiles themselves, or the tileset.res itself. Is it possible it retains some sort of metadata about transparency and hangs onto it?

Also unsure about why setting the opacity to over 1.0 fixed it.

This might not be reproducible, but figured I'd post it anyway in case someone else ran into it.

Cheers

data.title: 3D editor viewport turns black when editing a MeshInstance
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):** Windows 10, Godot Git https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/0a6446ff361f1674649e1625eb5868478d998091, NVIDIA

**Issue description:** The main 3D editor viewport turns black when editing a MeshInstance (such as a CubeMesh).

![Broken 3D viewport when editing a MeshInstance](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180032/30826438-e870283a-a236-11e7-97e1-6e4c22298393.png)

Once this happens, this error is spammed in the console:

```
ERROR: _gl_debug_print: GL ERROR: Source: OpenGL        Type: Error     ID: 1282        Severity: High  Message: GL_INVALID_OPERATION error generated. Texture name does not refer to a texture object generated by OpenGL.
   At: drivers\gles3\rasterizer_gles3.cpp:122
```

Note that you can work around this issue by resizing the editor window – the issue should no longer appear until you restart the editor.

**Steps to reproduce:** Open the demo project attached below, then edit the CubeMesh resource which is in the MeshInstance. Do not resize the editor window before doing this (else, this bug will not occur).

**Link to minimal example project:** [godot-demo-yamt.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1330596/godot-demo-yamt.zip)

data.title: Compilation failure on OpenBSD (crash_handler_x11.cpp:56: undefined reference to `backtrace_symbols')
data.body:
# I'd like to preface this by saying YES, godot is compatible with OpenBSD. I've successfully compiled 2.1.3 in the past.
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
OpenBSD Current AMD64 from 2017/09/24 
Scons V2.5.1
LLVM 5.0.0
libexecinfo 0.3
Latest Godot from Github
 
**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
By default, OpenBSD stores system libraries in _/usr/include_ and all other libraries in _/usr/local/include_. By default, Clang doesn't look for libraries in _/usr/local/include_ but I've added _C_INCLUDE_PATH_ in my _~/.profile_ to account for this. However, it seems Scons isn't passing these environment variable to Clang which fails to find the libraries for compilation.

To demonstrate this behaviour, If I was to write a small test program

> #include "execinfo.h"
> #include "stdio.h"
> int main() {
> printf("Hello World\n");
> return(0); }

and compile it without the environment variable added in my .profile, Clang would fail to find any libraries that are not part of OpenBSD's base system libraries.

> $ clang test.c 
> test.c:1:10: fatal error: 'execinfo.h' file not found
> #include "execinfo.h"
>          ^~~~~~~~~~~~
> 1 error generated.

After I added the environment variable in my .profile, Clang compiles without issue. 

> $ clang test.c
> $ file a.out
> a.out: ELF 64-bit LSB shared object, x86-64, version 1


Despite the environment variable being in my profile and being passed through Scons, compilation fails due to Clang not finding the libraries in question.

> $ file /usr/local/include/execinfo.h                                            
> /usr/local/include/execinfo.h: ASCII C program text
> $ scons platform=x11 use_llvm=yes CCFLAGS="/usr/local/include" CFLAGS="/usr/local/include" C_INCLUDE_PATH="/usr/local/include"
> scons: Reading SConscript files ...
> Could not detect MinGW. Ensure its binaries are in your PATH or that MINGW32_PREFIX or MINGW64_PREFIX are properly defined.
> ALSA libraries not found, disabling driver
> PulseAudio development libraries not found, disabling driver
> cdir is: /home/gjp/Git/godot
> Checking for C header file mntent.h... no
> scons: done reading SConscript files.
> scons: Building targets ...
> [Initial build] Compiling ==> platform/x11/godot_x11.cpp
> [Initial build] Compiling ==> platform/x11/context_gl_x11.cpp
> [Initial build] Compiling ==> platform/x11/crash_handler_x11.cpp
> platform/x11/crash_handler_x11.cpp:40:10: fatal error: 'execinfo.h' file not found
> #include <execinfo.h>
>          ^~~~~~~~~~~~
> 1 error generated.
> scons: *** [platform/x11/crash_handler_x11.x11.tools.64.llvm.o] Error 1
> scons: building terminated because of errors.
> 

**Steps to reproduce:**
Install [OpenBSD Current](https://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD/snapshots/amd64/) on a VM or bare metal. Remember to install ALL package sets. If you have any trouble, [consult the installation guide](https://www.openbsd.org/faq/faq4.html).

Great! Now as root, verify the installpath and install libexecinfo, llvm, scons and git:

`cat /etc/installurl`
`https://ftp.openbsd.org/pub/OpenBSD`
`pkg_add git llvm libexecinfo scons`

Then, clone Godot git repo

`git clone https://github.com/godotengine/godot
`
Don't forget to add C_INCLUDE_PATH to your .profile, you should also relogin for changes to take effect. 

`echo "export C_INCLUDE_PATH=/usr/local/include" >> ~/.profile
`
Finally, start the compilation

`scons platform=x11 use_llvm=yes builtin_openssl=yes`

data.title: Enhance iOS export
data.body:
- The export process now builds complete .ipa on macOS, instead of just
   creating XCode project.

 - The project includes Capabilities games usually require: Game Center,
   Push Notifications, In-App Purchase.

 - Icons and launch screens can be specified in export preset.

data.title: FileSystemDock will now remove files/dirs to trashcan using OS::move_to_trash
data.body: Instead of removing files permanently they are now moved to trashcan using a new function OS::move_to_trash. Also dirs can be removed as well.

data.title: Inherited CollisionShape2D ignoring the Shape2D
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Windows 10 Godot 2.1.3 

**Issue description:**
When inheriting a scene with a CollisionShape2D node, the inherited scene doesn't overwrite the parent's shape. It should since it is an inherited scene and that's what inheritance is aimed for :P


**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a test scene with a StaticBody2D as ground for testing purposes
1. Create any physics character (RigidBody2D or Kinematicbody2D)
1. Add a CollisionShape2D to it, do not create a Shape2D yet
1. Create an inherited scene using the above scene as parent
1. Now Add a Shape2D to this scene
1. Instantiate it in the test scene with the ground
1. Apply a movement so it can collide with the ground

Watch it passing by the ground.

Now repeat the same process starting in the 3rd step, but now add a Shape2D to the parent scene

Test it again and now it collides.

I couldn't fix this even when I try to manually add the Shape2D using GDScript.

data.title: Extract logging logic
data.body:
Previously logging logic was scattered over OS class implementations
with plenty of duplication. Major changes in this commit:

 - Extracted logging logic into a separate Logger hierarchy. It allows
   easy configuration of logging mechanism depending on compile-time or
   run-time configuration.

 - Implemented RotatedFileLogger which is usually used with StdLogger,
   providing persistency of logs. It is often important to be able to
   obtain logs of the game even in production to be able to understand
   what happened prior to some problem. On mobile there previously was
   no way to obtain the logs aside from having the device connected to
   your machine.

 - flush() is not performed in release mode for every logged line. It
   is only performed for errors.

data.title: Add types to scons command-line options
data.body:
I keep calling `scons` with invalid variable values and it never complains. With the merging of #11563, we can use the `*Variable` functions to make this more explicit. `EnumVariable` limits inputs to a small set of values. `BoolVariable` allows a variety of inputs for True and False, but validates and simplifies all of them into a boolean. This really helps with all the tests since there are no longer 4 different ways to check something (`==`/`!=` `yes`/`no`).

This is a bit large, but I tried to split it up into small-ish commits.

data.title: 3.0 Particles need ability to emit from mesh surface
data.body:
there could actually exist a way if arrays were available as shader's uniforms, one can pass an array of verts and their normals to the control shader and it will place particles on random verts.

but i think particle system needs a better way for this, i think user should specify emitting shape in the particle system's settings, not the control shader, so that control shader runs on already properly placed particle

data.title: Fix Inverted "Explosiveness" Parameter Range
data.body:
When worked on porting Particles System demo to Godot 3 as well as documenting the Particles-Particles2D node, I noticed a small but important issue. The explosiveness range in Godot 2 differs from Godot 3, it's inverted.

- Min value in Godot 2 == Max value in Godot 3
- Max value in Godot 2 == Min value in Godot 3

This could give any trouble when porting Godot 2 projects (which rely on Particles-Particles2D node) to Godot 3, because the behavior of the particles when played in Godot 2 will be different in Godot 3.

- Godot 2, on Explosiveness : 
Min (0) --> Max (1) == Less Explosion --> More Explosion (I think, this is desired)
- Godot 3, on Explosiveness : 
Min (0) --> Max (1) == More Explosion --> Less Explosion (I think, this is not desired)

By solving this issue, Godot users who port their Godot 2.x projects with Particles-Paricles2D node(s) inside will be having smoother transition and greater experience. This PR tried to help on it. :-)

data.title: Added the ability to revert to initial value in editor settings.
data.body:
now it is possible to revert to initial editor settings.

![screenshot from 2017-09-24 22-25-34](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1103897/30791434-077b3ab8-a178-11e7-809a-a6b27c52dfca.png)

data.title: Bump required scons version to 0.98.1.
data.body:
* Environment.AddPostAction() and the global AlwaysBuild() were added in 0.93, so requiring 0.14 is broken.
* Environment.Decider and Glob were added in some intermediate 0.97 release.
* The Variables object was added in 0.98.1.

This is entirely based on function calls; if behaviour has changed that may require a newer version, but I don't really feel liking looking that up as I'm not that crazy about scons.

data.title: Windows MSVC wrong or misspelled target value will fail to compile
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 3.0 master https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/1f4685375f2d2e36a2e19e67ac9f614b8c99ea28

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
If you misspell or write the `target` value wrong the compilation will fail.

`target=debug` Compiles
`target=release_debug` Compiles
`target=debug_release` Fails to compile with the error below
`target=this_is_broken_pls_fix` Fails to compile with the error below

**Steps to reproduce:**
Compile with a wrong `target` on windows using msvc

[Compilation log](https://hastebin.com/joxotijoci.erl)
